TCFD Report Notes

1. Foreword / Executive Summary

Climate change represents both a critical challenge and an opportunity for our business. We recognize that addressing climate-related risks and capitalizing on emerging opportunities is essential to our long-term success and resilience. üåç

This report outlines our approach to climate governance, strategy, risk management, and performance metrics in alignment with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations. Throughout 2023, we've strengthened our climate response by:

  • Fully integrating climate risks and opportunities into our Enterprise Risk Management system[1]
  • Developing a climate transition plan aligned with a 1.5¬∞C world[2]
  • Adopting an 'electric first' approach to capital investment decisions[3]
  • Expanding climate-related accountability across senior management[4]

We're committed to transparency and continuous improvement as we navigate the transition to a low-carbon economy. This report demonstrates our progress and outlines our path forward. üéØ

2. Introduction

The Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) provides a framework for organizations to disclose climate-related financial information to stakeholders. Our TCFD reporting covers four core pillars: Governance, Strategy, Risk Management, and Metrics & Targets.

Our TCFD Journey:

We've conducted organization-wide scenario analysis that influences our risk identification, business model resilience, and target setting.[5] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[6]

We're continuing to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[7] We're also planning to refresh our scenario modelling and double materiality assessment, and engaging biodiversity specialists to identify additional risks and opportunities.[8]

Reporting Period: This report covers the period from January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023.

3. Governance

3.1. Board Oversight

Our board-level Risk and Audit Committee provides oversight of climate and sustainability-related risks, ensuring they are properly identified and managed.[9] The Committee has specific oversight of scenario modelling for climate risks, ensuring our approach remains robust and forward-looking.[10]

Our Board of Directors has been engaged throughout the year on our climate strategy. We've used our TCFD framework and scenario analysis to help the Board understand the qualitative impacts of climate change on our business across short, medium, and long-term time horizons.[11]

The Risk Committee reviewed top-down and emerging risks at the end of 2022, with risks quantified using a set methodology. These risks are continuously reviewed by our Risk Committee and board-level Risk and Audit Committee throughout the year.[12] üìä

3.2. Management's Role

Our Executive Management Board has been regularly informed of progress with our Sustainability Strategy throughout the year and has been involved in key initiatives, opportunities and collaborations.[13]

Our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer plays a central role in climate governance, being directly involved in scenario planning exercises and assessment of opportunities and risks.[14]

Climate-Related Targets & Accountability:

Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions.[15] These targets were refreshed for 2023 and will be further updated in 2024 as we set new targets.[16]

We're expanding accountability more widely across the organization, with more employees being held accountable for delivering our sustainability strategy as it relates to climate change.[17] Management targets will be refreshed for 2025 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios, risks and opportunities.[18] üí™

4. Strategy

4.1. Climate-related Risks & Opportunities

We've conducted a comprehensive assessment of climate-related risks and opportunities across our business. Our scenario analysis is organization-wide and covers both our direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[19]

Physical Risks Identified:

We've identified several acute and chronic physical risks that could impact our operations:[20]

  • Acute risks: Floods, wildfires, storms, heat waves, cyclones, heavy precipitation, and drought
  • Chronic risks: Changing precipitation patterns, coastal erosion, heat stress, increased severity of extreme weather events, and sea level rise

These physical risks are assessed as having medium-high magnitude with impacts anticipated over the medium to long-term. üåä

Transition Risks & Opportunities:

We've identified concentration of risks around:[21]

  • Non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation
  • Technology transitions including data access/monitoring systems and transition to lower emissions technology
  • Investment requirements in new technologies

Our 'electric first' approach to investment decisions for ground support equipment and vehicles demonstrates how we're capitalizing on opportunities in the transition to lower-carbon operations.[22] ‚ö°

We've conducted a comprehensive strategic review of our business model and value chain to identify climate-related risks and opportunities.[19] Our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system, Corestream, fully integrates all climate-related risks and opportunities discovered through our TCFD implementation process.[20]

Risk Identification:

We've identified climate risks concentrated in several key areas of our business model and value chain:[21]

  • Regulatory & Liability Exposure: Risks around non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation[22]
  • Technology Risks: Data access/monitoring systems, transition to lower emissions technology, and investment in new technologies[23]
  • Revenue Impact: We've identified that approximately ¬£20M of revenue (1-10% of total) is vulnerable to transition risks, with an additional ¬£5M from physical risks[24]

Opportunities:

We're capitalizing on climate-related opportunities through:

  • Innovation and environmental transformation grants[25]
  • Collaboration with industry partners to drive new technology opportunities and support the aviation services transition[26]
  • Maximizing access to grants and subsidies[27]
  • Collaborating with suppliers on improved leasing terms where sustainability financing provides financial benefits[28]

4.2. Impact on Business, Strategy & Financial Planning

Climate-related risks and opportunities have been integrated into our strategic planning and financial decision-making processes. üíº

Strategic Integration:

We utilize scenario analysis to refine our understanding of climate change impacts on our business, incorporating this analysis into new business opportunity assessments.[29] We've refined our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis outcomes into new business opportunity assessments.[30]

Our scenario analysis directly influences:[31]

  • Risk and opportunities identification, assessment and management
  • Resilience of business model and strategy
  • Target setting and transition planning

Financial Planning Elements Affected:

Climate considerations have impacted several key financial planning elements:

  • Revenues: As noted above, we've identified approximately ¬£20M of revenue vulnerable to transition risks and ¬£5M from physical risks[32]
  • Capital Expenditures (CAPEX): We're taking an 'electric first' approach to all investment decisions for new ground support equipment and vehicles, and we expect increased investment in sustainable solutions to support our net-zero transition[33]
  • Investment Procedures: We've expanded our sustainable procurement approach and capital investment procedures across our business[34]

Decision-Making Updates:

Our decision-making processes are being updated to reflect sustainability and climate change considerations, with plans for further refresh in 2024 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios.[35] üìä

4.3. Time Horizons

We've used our TCFD framework and scenario analysis to help our Executive Management Board and Board of Directors understand the qualitative impacts of climate change on our business across short, medium, and long-term time horizons.[36] We're actively working to quantify these impacts to set our strategic direction for mitigating climate risks and maximizing opportunities.[37]

Our strategy considers how our financial performance, cash flow, and financial position will change across all time horizons.[38] ‚è∞

4.4. Scenario Analysis & Resilience

We completed organization-wide scenario analysis that covers both our direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[39] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises.[40]

Transition Planning:

We have a climate transition plan which aligns with a 1.5¬∞C world, demonstrating our commitment to strategic alignment with climate goals.[41] üåç

Ongoing Refinement:

We're continuing to refine our understanding of each scenario and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[42] We're currently undertaking a refresh of our scenario models and double materiality assessment, which may further impact our processes and priorities going forward.[43]

We're also engaging biodiversity specialists to help identify additional risks and opportunities, which will enhance our understanding of nature-related dependencies and impacts.[44] üå±

TCFD Report Notes

1. Foreword / Executive Summary

Climate change represents both a critical challenge and an opportunity for our business. We recognize that addressing climate-related risks and capitalizing on emerging opportunities is essential to our long-term success and resilience. üåç

This report outlines our approach to climate governance, strategy, risk management, and performance metrics in alignment with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations. Throughout 2023, we've strengthened our climate response by:

  • Fully integrating climate risks and opportunities into our Enterprise Risk Management system[1]
  • Developing a climate transition plan aligned with a 1.5¬∞C world[2]
  • Adopting an 'electric first' approach to capital investment decisions[3]
  • Expanding climate-related accountability across senior management[4]

We're committed to transparency and continuous improvement as we navigate the transition to a low-carbon economy. This report demonstrates our progress and outlines our path forward. üéØ

2. Introduction

The Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) provides a framework for organizations to disclose climate-related financial information to stakeholders. Our TCFD reporting covers four core pillars: Governance, Strategy, Risk Management, and Metrics & Targets.

Our TCFD Journey:

We've conducted organization-wide scenario analysis that influences our risk identification, business model resilience, and target setting.[5] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[6]

We're continuing to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[7] We're also planning to refresh our scenario modelling and double materiality assessment, and engaging biodiversity specialists to identify additional risks and opportunities.[8]

Reporting Period: This report covers the period from January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023.

TCFD STRATEGY C.3: (stage:IN_PROGRESS) Do you anticipate making any direct mitigation or adaptation efforts that will affect your ability to address climate-related risks and opportunities?

Yes, we anticipate making direct mitigation and adaptation efforts that will affect our ability to address climate-related risks and opportunities. üå±

Strategic Integration: We've refined our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis into new business opportunity assessments, ensuring climate considerations are embedded in decision-making.

Transition Planning: We have a climate transition plan that aligns with a 1.5¬∞C world, demonstrating our commitment to meaningful climate action.

Target Setting: We've assigned climate-related targets to senior management focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions. These targets were refreshed for 2023 and will be further updated in 2024 as we set new targets and refine our decision-making processes.

Expanding Accountability: We're expanding these targets more widely across the organization, with more employees being held accountable for delivering our sustainability strategy as it relates to climate change. Investment Approach: We take an 'electric first' approach to all investment decisions around new ground support equipment and vehicles, and have expanded our sustainable procurement approach and capital investment procedures across our business. We expect increased investment in sustainable solutions to support our transition to net-zero. ‚ö°

  • We continue to refine our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis outcomes üîÑ
  • We take an 'electric first' approach to all investment decisions around new ground support equipment and vehicles, and have expanded our sustainable procurement approach üîå
  • We're expanding accountability more widely, with more employees being accountable for delivery of our strategy as it reflects sustainability and climate change üí™

TCFD Report Notes

1. Foreword / Executive Summary

Climate change represents both a critical challenge and an opportunity for our business. We recognize that addressing climate-related risks and capitalizing on emerging opportunities is essential to our long-term success and resilience. üåç

This report outlines our approach to climate governance, strategy, risk management, and performance metrics in alignment with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations. Throughout 2023, we've strengthened our climate response by:

  • Fully integrating climate risks and opportunities into our Enterprise Risk Management system[1]
  • Developing a climate transition plan aligned with a 1.5¬∞C world[2]
  • Adopting an 'electric first' approach to capital investment decisions[3]
  • Expanding climate-related accountability across senior management[4]

We're committed to transparency and continuous improvement as we navigate the transition to a low-carbon economy. This report demonstrates our progress and outlines our path forward. üéØ

2. Introduction

The Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) provides a framework for organizations to disclose climate-related financial information to stakeholders. Our TCFD reporting covers four core pillars: Governance, Strategy, Risk Management, and Metrics & Targets.

Our TCFD Journey:

We've conducted organization-wide scenario analysis that influences our risk identification, business model resilience, and target setting.[5] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[6]

We're continuing to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[7] We're also planning to refresh our scenario modelling and double materiality assessment, and engaging biodiversity specialists to identify additional risks and opportunities.[8]

Reporting Period: This report covers the period from January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023.

sourceSlices.question: How does the business intend to meet any climate related targets, including greenhouse gas emissions targets, that it has set?
sourceSlices.answer:

  • Ongoing Refinement: We continue to refine our understanding through scenario analysis and are engaging specialists in biodiversity to assist us in identifying risks and opportunities. We will be refreshing our scenario modelling and double materiality assessment, which may alter our approach and priorities.

Our process includes:

  • Integration: Climate-related risks are managed within our multi-disciplinary organization-wide risk management process

TCFD Report Notes

1. Foreword / Executive Summary

Climate change represents both a critical challenge and an opportunity for our business. We recognize that addressing climate-related risks and capitalizing on emerging opportunities is essential to our long-term success and resilience. üåç

This report outlines our approach to climate governance, strategy, risk management, and performance metrics in alignment with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations. Throughout 2023, we've strengthened our climate response by:

  • Fully integrating climate risks and opportunities into our Enterprise Risk Management system[1]
  • Developing a climate transition plan aligned with a 1.5¬∞C world[2]
  • Adopting an 'electric first' approach to capital investment decisions[3]
  • Expanding climate-related accountability across senior management[4]

We're committed to transparency and continuous improvement as we navigate the transition to a low-carbon economy. This report demonstrates our progress and outlines our path forward. üéØ

2. Introduction

The Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) provides a framework for organizations to disclose climate-related financial information to stakeholders. Our TCFD reporting covers four core pillars: Governance, Strategy, Risk Management, and Metrics & Targets.

Our TCFD Journey:

We've conducted organization-wide scenario analysis that influences our risk identification, business model resilience, and target setting.[5] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[6]

We're continuing to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[7] We're also planning to refresh our scenario modelling and double materiality assessment, and engaging biodiversity specialists to identify additional risks and opportunities.[8]

Reporting Period: This report covers the period from January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023.

3. Governance

3.1. Board Oversight

Our board-level Risk and Audit Committee provides oversight of climate and sustainability-related risks, ensuring they are properly identified and managed.[9] The Committee has specific oversight of scenario modelling for climate risks, ensuring our approach remains robust and forward-looking.[10]

Our Board of Directors has been engaged throughout the year on our climate strategy. We've used our TCFD framework and scenario analysis to help the Board understand the qualitative impacts of climate change on our business across short, medium, and long-term time horizons.[11]

The Risk Committee reviewed top-down and emerging risks at the end of 2022, with risks quantified using a set methodology. These risks are continuously reviewed by our Risk Committee and board-level Risk and Audit Committee throughout the year.[12] üìä

3.2. Management's Role

Our Executive Management Board has been regularly informed of progress with our Sustainability Strategy throughout the year and has been involved in key initiatives, opportunities and collaborations.[13]

Our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer plays a central role in climate governance, being directly involved in scenario planning exercises and assessment of opportunities and risks.[14]

Climate-Related Targets & Accountability:

Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions.[15] These targets were refreshed for 2023 and will be further updated in 2024 as we set new targets.[16]

We're expanding accountability more widely across the organization, with more employees being held accountable for delivering our sustainability strategy as it relates to climate change.[17] Management targets will be refreshed for 2025 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios, risks and opportunities.[18] üí™

4. Strategy

4.1. Climate-related Risks & Opportunities

We've conducted a comprehensive strategic review of our business model and value chain to identify climate-related risks and opportunities.[19] Our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system, Corestream, fully integrates all climate-related risks and opportunities discovered through our TCFD implementation process.[20]

Risk Identification:

We've identified climate risks concentrated in several key areas of our business model and value chain:[21]

  • Regulatory & Liability Exposure: Risks around non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation[22]
  • Technology Risks: Data access/monitoring systems, transition to lower emissions technology, and investment in new technologies[23]
  • Revenue Impact: We've identified that approximately ¬£20M of revenue (1-10% of total) is vulnerable to transition risks, with an additional ¬£5M from physical risks[24]

Opportunities:

We're capitalizing on climate-related opportunities through:

  • Innovation and environmental transformation grants[25]
  • Collaboration with industry partners to drive new technology opportunities and support the aviation services transition[26]
  • Maximizing access to grants and subsidies[27]
  • Collaborating with suppliers on improved leasing terms where sustainability financing provides financial benefits[28]

4.2. Impact on Business, Strategy & Financial Planning

Climate-related risks and opportunities have been integrated into our strategic planning and financial decision-making processes. üíº

Strategic Integration:

We utilize scenario analysis to refine our understanding of climate change impacts on our business, incorporating this analysis into new business opportunity assessments.[29] We've refined our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis outcomes into new business opportunity assessments.[30]

Our scenario analysis directly influences:[31]

  • Risk and opportunities identification, assessment and management
  • Resilience of business model and strategy
  • Target setting and transition planning

Financial Planning Elements Affected:

Climate considerations have impacted several key financial planning elements:

  • Revenues: As noted above, we've identified approximately ¬£20M of revenue vulnerable to transition risks and ¬£5M from physical risks[32]
  • Capital Expenditures (CAPEX): We're taking an 'electric first' approach to all investment decisions for new ground support equipment and vehicles, and we expect increased investment in sustainable solutions to support our net-zero transition[33]
  • Investment Procedures: We've expanded our sustainable procurement approach and capital investment procedures across our business[34]

Decision-Making Updates:

Our decision-making processes are being updated to reflect sustainability and climate change considerations, with plans for further refresh in 2024 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios.[35] üìä

4.3. Time Horizons

We've used our TCFD framework and scenario analysis to help our Executive Management Board and Board of Directors understand the qualitative impacts of climate change on our business across short, medium, and long-term time horizons.[36] We're actively working to quantify these impacts to set our strategic direction for mitigating climate risks and maximizing opportunities.[37]

Our strategy considers how our financial performance, cash flow, and financial position will change across all time horizons.[38] ‚è∞

4.4. Scenario Analysis & Resilience

We completed organization-wide scenario analysis that covers both our direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[39] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises.[40]

Transition Planning:

We have a climate transition plan which aligns with a 1.5¬∞C world, demonstrating our commitment to strategic alignment with climate goals.[41] üåç

Ongoing Refinement:

We're continuing to refine our understanding of each scenario and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[42] We're currently undertaking a refresh of our scenario models and double materiality assessment, which may further impact our processes and priorities going forward.[43]

We're also engaging biodiversity specialists to help identify additional risks and opportunities, which will enhance our understanding of nature-related dependencies and impacts.[44] üå±

Management's Role

Our Executive Management Board plays an active role in climate governance and has been regularly informed of progress with our Sustainability Strategy throughout the year.[13] The Board has been involved in key initiatives, opportunities and collaborations related to climate action.

Senior Leadership Accountability: Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions. These targets were refreshed for 2023 and will be further updated in 2024 as we set new targets and refine our decision-making processes.[14] We're expanding these targets more widely across the organization, with more employees being held accountable for delivering our sustainability strategy as it relates to climate change.[15]

Cross-Functional Integration: We have a cross-functional risk group that assesses all enterprise risks and participates in climate risk analysis, ensuring climate considerations are integrated across different internal functions.[16]

Direct Involvement in Strategy: Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[17] This ensures that climate considerations are embedded in strategic decision-making at the highest levels of management. üíº

4. Strategy

4.1. Climate-related Risks & Opportunities

We've conducted a comprehensive assessment of climate-related risks and opportunities affecting our business. Our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system, Corestream, fully integrates all climate-related risks and opportunities discovered through our TCFD implementation process.[18]

Physical Risks Identified:

Acute Physical Risks:
We've identified several acute physical risks including floods (coastal, fluvial, pluvial, groundwater), wildfires, storms (including blizzards, dust, and sandstorms), heat waves, cyclones/hurricanes/typhoons, heavy precipitation (rain, hail, snow/ice), and drought.[19]

Chronic Physical Risks:
Our chronic physical risks include changing precipitation patterns and types, coastal erosion, heat stress, increased severity of extreme weather events, and sea level rise.[20] We've assessed these risks as having a medium-high magnitude with impacts anticipated over the medium to long-term.[21]

Transition Risks:
We've identified concentration of risks around non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation.[22] Technology risks include data access/monitoring systems, transition to lower emissions technology, and investment in new technologies.[23] We've identified that approximately ¬£20 million of revenue (1-10% of total) is vulnerable to transition risks.[24]

Opportunities:
We're capitalizing on opportunities through innovation and environmental transformation grants, and collaborating with industry partners to drive new technology opportunities and support the aviation services transition.[25] We're working with external advisors to maximize opportunities and access grants and subsidies, and collaborating with suppliers on improved terms for leasing assets where there's a financial benefit from sustainability financing.[26] üå±

4.2. Impact on Business, Strategy & Financial Planning

Climate risks and opportunities have directly influenced our business model, strategy, and financial planning across multiple dimensions.

Business Model Impact:
We've conducted a comprehensive strategic review of our business model and value chain in the context of climate risks and opportunities.[27] Our scenario analysis is organization-wide and covers both our direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[28]

Strategic Integration:
We've refined our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis into new business opportunity assessments.[29] We have a climate transition plan that aligns with a 1.5¬∞C world, demonstrating our commitment to meaningful climate action.[30]

Financial Planning Impact:
Climate risks and opportunities have affected our financial planning in two key areas: revenues and capital expenditures (CAPEX).[31] We've adopted an 'electric first' approach to all investment decisions for new ground support equipment and vehicles, and have expanded our sustainable procurement approach and capital investment procedures across the business.[32] We expect increased investment in sustainable solutions to support our transition to net-zero.[33]

Decision-Making Evolution:
Our scenario analysis directly influences our risk and opportunities identification, assessment and management; resilience of business model and strategy; and target setting and transition planning.[34] üíº

4.3. Time Horizons

We assess climate-related risks and opportunities across three distinct time horizons, aligned with our strategic decision-making processes:

Short-term (1-5 years):
Our short-term horizon aligns with our rolling 5-year financial planning cycle. We have SBTi-validated targets for a 50% reduction in Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2030.[35]

Medium-term (6-10 years):
Our medium-term horizon bridges our short-term operational planning and long-term strategic vision, allowing us to assess transitional impacts and opportunities.

Long-term (16-25 years):
Our long-term horizon extends to our net-zero commitment and aligns with climate scenario modeling extending to 2050.[36]

We assess risks across all three time horizons using our multi-disciplinary enterprise-wide risk management process and IPCC Climate Change Projections.[37] Our Risk & Audit Committee provides oversight, and our Executive Management Board receives regular updates throughout the year.[38] ‚è∞

4.4. Scenario Analysis & Resilience

We've conducted comprehensive scenario analysis to test the resilience of our strategy under different climate futures.

Scenario Approach:
We developed a bespoke climate transition scenario using both qualitative and quantitative approaches on an organization-wide basis.[39] Our scenario analysis is conducted annually and incorporates IPCC Climate Change Projections.[40]

1.5¬∞C Alignment:
Our climate transition plan aligns with a 1.5¬∞C world scenario, which inherently assumes increasingly stringent climate policies across jurisdictions to meet Paris Agreement targets.[41]

Strategic Application:
We've used our TCFD framework and scenario analysis to help our Executive Management Board and Board of Directors understand the qualitative impacts of climate change on our business across short, medium, and long-term time horizons.[42] We're actively working to quantify these impacts to set our strategic direction for mitigating climate risks and maximizing opportunities.[43]

Ongoing Refinement:
We're continuing to refine our understanding of each scenario and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[44] We're planning to refresh our scenario modeling and double materiality assessment, and we're engaging biodiversity specialists to identify additional risks and opportunities.[45] üéØ

TCFD Report Notes

1. Foreword / Executive Summary

5.1. Identification & Assessment

We identify and assess climate-related risks and opportunities within our existing Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system called Corestream.[45] All climate risks and opportunities discovered through our TCFD implementation process are fully integrated within our updated ERM processes and form a core part of our risk assessment procedures.[46]

Risk Categories Assessed:

Transition Risks: 🔄

  • Policy and legal risks (including non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation)
  • Technology risks (data access/monitoring systems, transition to lower emissions technology, investment in new technologies)
  • Market risks (changing customer behavior, uncertainty in market signals, increased cost of raw materials)
  • Reputation risks (shifts in consumer preferences, stigmatization of sector, increased stakeholder concern)

Physical Risks: 🌍

  • Acute: Floods, wildfires, storms, heat waves, cyclones, heavy precipitation, drought
  • Chronic: Changing precipitation patterns, coastal erosion, heat stress, increased severity of extreme weather events, sea level rise

Assessment Process:

Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer directly participate in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[47] We conduct awareness sessions on climate change and external factors, and communicate sustainability plans to over 100 senior managers during M100 update sessions.[48]

Our Risk Committee reviewed top-down and emerging risks at the end of 2022, with risks quantified using a set methodology.[49] 📊

Regular Review Cycle:

Climate risks are continuously reviewed by our Risk Committee and board-level Risk and Audit Committee throughout the year.[50] Executive and senior management teams assess potential impacts at least twice a year through our ERM system.[51]

Scenario Analysis Integration:

We've refined our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis into new business opportunity assessments.[52] This ensures climate considerations are embedded in strategic decision-making from the outset. Our scenario analysis is organization-wide and covers both direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[53]

Cross-Functional Approach:

We have a cross-functional risk group that assesses all enterprise risks and participates in climate risk analysis, ensuring climate considerations are integrated across different internal functions.[54] 🤝

Ongoing Refinement:

We're continuing to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[55] We're also engaging biodiversity specialists to help identify additional risks and opportunities.[56]

5.3. Integration into Overall Risk Management

Climate-related risks and opportunities are fully integrated within our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) processes and are a core part of our risk assessment procedures.[57] This integration ensures that climate considerations are not treated as separate or siloed issues, but rather as fundamental components of our overall risk landscape. ✅

Our scenario analysis directly influences:

  • Risk and opportunities identification, assessment and management
  • Resilience of business model and strategy
  • Target setting and transition planning[58]

5. Risk Management

5.1. Identification & Assessment

We identify and assess climate-related risks and opportunities within our existing Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system called Corestream.[45] All climate risks and opportunities discovered through our TCFD implementation process are fully integrated within our updated ERM processes and form a core part of our risk assessment procedures.[46]

Risk Categories Assessed:

Transition Risks: üîÑ

  • Policy and legal risks (including non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation)
  • Technology risks (data access/monitoring systems, transition to lower emissions technology, investment in new technologies)
  • Market risks (changing customer behavior, uncertainty in market signals, increased cost of raw materials)
  • Reputation risks (shifts in consumer preferences, stigmatization of sector, increased stakeholder concern)

Physical Risks: üåç

  • Acute: Floods, wildfires, storms, heat waves, cyclones, heavy precipitation, drought
  • Chronic: Changing precipitation patterns, coastal erosion, heat stress, increased severity of extreme weather events, sea level rise

Assessment Process:

Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer directly participate in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[47] We conduct awareness sessions on climate change and external factors, and communicate sustainability plans to over 100 senior managers during M100 update sessions.[48]

Our Risk Committee reviewed top-down and emerging risks at the end of 2022, with risks quantified using a set methodology.[49] üìä

5.2. Risk Management Process

Our climate risk management process is embedded within our comprehensive Enterprise Risk Management framework and follows a structured approach:

Regular Review Cycle:

Climate risks are continuously reviewed by our Risk Committee and board-level Risk and Audit Committee throughout the year.[50] Executive and senior management teams assess potential impacts at least twice a year through our ERM system.[51]

Scenario Analysis Integration:

We've refined our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis into new business opportunity assessments.[52] This ensures climate considerations are embedded in strategic decision-making from the outset. Our scenario analysis is organization-wide and covers both direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[53]

Cross-Functional Approach:

We have a cross-functional risk group that assesses all enterprise risks and participates in climate risk analysis, ensuring climate considerations are integrated across different internal functions.[54] ü§ù

Ongoing Refinement:

We're continuing to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[55] We're also engaging biodiversity specialists to help identify additional risks and opportunities.[56]

5.3. Integration into Overall Risk Management

Climate-related risks and opportunities are fully integrated within our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) processes and are a core part of our risk assessment procedures.[57] This integration ensures that climate considerations are not treated as separate or siloed issues, but rather as fundamental components of our overall risk landscape. ‚úÖ

Strategic Integration:

Our scenario analysis directly influences:

  • Risk and opportunities identification, assessment and management
  • Resilience of business model and strategy
  • Target setting and transition planning[58]

Governance Linkage:

Our Risk & Audit Committee is responsible for ensuring climate and sustainability-related risks are identified and managed, with oversight of scenario modelling for climate risks.[59] This provides clear accountability and oversight at the board level.

Management Accountability:

Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions, ensuring accountability at the management level.[60] We're expanding accountability more widely, with more employees being responsible for delivery of our strategy as it reflects sustainability and climate change.[61] üí™

sourceSlices.question: Does the governance body set, monitor, and incentivise targets clearly aligned to climate related risks and opportunities?
sourceSlices.answer:
Yes, we do set and monitor targets aligned to climate-related risks and opportunities, though our incentive structures are still developing. üéØ

Target Setting & Monitoring:
Our governance body, including the Risk & Audit Committee and Executive Management Board, oversees climate-related targets. Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. These targets were refreshed for 2023 and are being further updated for 2024-2025 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios, risks and opportunities.

The Chief Governance and Sustainability Officer has day-to-day responsibility for sustainability targets and reports directly to the board annually on environmental issues. The Risk & Audit Committee meets quarterly to ensure climate and sustainability-related risks are identified and managed, with oversight of scenario modelling for climate risks.

Incentivisation:
While we have goals assigned to various management teams related to achieving our environmental targets and objectives, these are not yet broad goals at C-suite level. We acknowledge this is a core consideration for the future and plan to introduce monetary incentives for the management of climate change issues within the next two years. üíº

sourceSlices.question: What metrics does the business use to monitor progress towards reaching each climate related targets?
sourceSlices.answer:
Hey! üëã So here's the deal with how we track our climate targets:

  • Absolute emissions reduction - We're tracking total gross global Scope 1 & 2 emissions in metric tons CO2e to see if we're hitting our reduction targets üìâ

  • Energy consumption - We monitor total energy consumption in MWh (excluding feedstocks) and track fuel consumption by type
  • Sustainable procurement - We measure progress through our 'electric first' approach to ground support equipment and vehicle investments ‚ö°

Our Board-level governance includes measuring progress towards environmental science-based targets and corporate environmental targets on an annual basis, so there's proper oversight at the top! üéØ

TCFD Report Notes

1. Foreword / Executive Summary

Climate change represents both a critical challenge and an opportunity for our business. We recognize that addressing climate-related risks and capitalizing on emerging opportunities is essential to our long-term success and resilience. üåç

This report outlines our approach to climate governance, strategy, risk management, and performance metrics in alignment with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations. Throughout 2023, we've strengthened our climate response by:

  • Fully integrating climate risks and opportunities into our Enterprise Risk Management system[1]
  • Developing a climate transition plan aligned with a 1.5¬∞C world[2]
  • Adopting an 'electric first' approach to capital investment decisions[3]
  • Expanding climate-related accountability across senior management[4]

We're committed to transparency and continuous improvement as we navigate the transition to a low-carbon economy. This report demonstrates our progress and outlines our path forward. üéØ

2. Introduction

The Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) provides a framework for organizations to disclose climate-related financial information to stakeholders. Our TCFD reporting covers four core pillars: Governance, Strategy, Risk Management, and Metrics & Targets.

Our TCFD Journey:

We've conducted organization-wide scenario analysis that influences our risk identification, business model resilience, and target setting.[5] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[6]

We're continuing to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[7] We're also planning to refresh our scenario modelling and double materiality assessment, and engaging biodiversity specialists to identify additional risks and opportunities.[8]

Reporting Period: This report covers the period from January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023.

3. Governance

3.1. Board Oversight

Our board-level Risk and Audit Committee provides oversight of climate and sustainability-related risks, ensuring they are properly identified and managed.[9] The Committee has specific oversight of scenario modelling for climate risks, ensuring our approach remains robust and forward-looking.[10]

Our Board of Directors has been engaged throughout the year on our climate strategy. We've used our TCFD framework and scenario analysis to help the Board understand the qualitative impacts of climate change on our business across short, medium, and long-term time horizons.[11]

The Risk Committee reviewed top-down and emerging risks at the end of 2022, with risks quantified using a set methodology. These risks are continuously reviewed by our Risk Committee and board-level Risk and Audit Committee throughout the year.[12] üìä

3.2. Management's Role

Our Executive Management Board has been regularly informed of progress with our Sustainability Strategy throughout the year and has been involved in key initiatives, opportunities and collaborations.[13]

Our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer plays a central role in climate governance, being directly involved in scenario planning exercises and assessment of opportunities and risks.[14]

Climate-Related Targets & Accountability:

Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions.[15] These targets were refreshed for 2023 and will be further updated in 2024 as we set new targets.[16]

We're expanding accountability more widely across the organization, with more employees being held accountable for delivering our sustainability strategy as it relates to climate change.[17] Management targets will be refreshed for 2025 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios, risks and opportunities.[18] üí™

4. Strategy

4.1. Climate-related Risks & Opportunities

We've conducted a comprehensive assessment of climate-related risks and opportunities across our business. Our scenario analysis is organization-wide and covers both our direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[19]

Physical Risks Identified:

We've identified several acute and chronic physical risks that could impact our operations:[20]

  • Acute risks: Floods, wildfires, storms, heat waves, cyclones, heavy precipitation, and drought
  • Chronic risks: Changing precipitation patterns, coastal erosion, heat stress, increased severity of extreme weather events, and sea level rise

These physical risks are assessed as having medium-high magnitude with impacts anticipated over the medium to long-term. üåä

Transition Risks & Opportunities:

We've identified concentration of risks around:[21]

  • Non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation
  • Technology transitions including data access/monitoring systems and transition to lower emissions technology
  • Investment requirements in new technologies

Our 'electric first' approach to investment decisions for ground support equipment and vehicles demonstrates how we're capitalizing on opportunities in the transition to lower-carbon operations.[22] ‚ö°

We've conducted a comprehensive strategic review of our business model and value chain to identify climate-related risks and opportunities.[19] Our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system, Corestream, fully integrates all climate-related risks and opportunities discovered through our TCFD implementation process.[20]

Risk Identification:

We've identified climate risks concentrated in several key areas of our business model and value chain:[21]

  • Regulatory & Liability Exposure: Risks around non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation[22]
  • Technology Risks: Data access/monitoring systems, transition to lower emissions technology, and investment in new technologies[23]
  • Revenue Impact: We've identified that approximately ¬£20M of revenue (1-10% of total) is vulnerable to transition risks, with an additional ¬£5M from physical risks[24]

Opportunities:

We're capitalizing on climate-related opportunities through:

  • Innovation and environmental transformation grants[25]
  • Collaboration with industry partners to drive new technology opportunities and support the aviation services transition[26]
  • Maximizing access to grants and subsidies[27]
  • Collaborating with suppliers on improved leasing terms where sustainability financing provides financial benefits[28]

4.2. Impact on Business, Strategy & Financial Planning

Climate-related risks and opportunities have been integrated into our strategic planning and financial decision-making processes. üíº

Strategic Integration:

We utilize scenario analysis to refine our understanding of climate change impacts on our business, incorporating this analysis into new business opportunity assessments.[29] We've refined our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis outcomes into new business opportunity assessments.[30]

Our scenario analysis directly influences:[31]

  • Risk and opportunities identification, assessment and management
  • Resilience of business model and strategy
  • Target setting and transition planning

Financial Planning Elements Affected:

Climate considerations have impacted several key financial planning elements:

  • Revenues: As noted above, we've identified approximately ¬£20M of revenue vulnerable to transition risks and ¬£5M from physical risks[32]
  • Capital Expenditures (CAPEX): We're taking an 'electric first' approach to all investment decisions for new ground support equipment and vehicles, and we expect increased investment in sustainable solutions to support our net-zero transition[33]
  • Investment Procedures: We've expanded our sustainable procurement approach and capital investment procedures across our business[34]

Decision-Making Updates:

Our decision-making processes are being updated to reflect sustainability and climate change considerations, with plans for further refresh in 2024 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios.[35] üìä

4.3. Time Horizons

We've used our TCFD framework and scenario analysis to help our Executive Management Board and Board of Directors understand the qualitative impacts of climate change on our business across short, medium, and long-term time horizons.[36] We're actively working to quantify these impacts to set our strategic direction for mitigating climate risks and maximizing opportunities.[37]

Our strategy considers how our financial performance, cash flow, and financial position will change across all time horizons.[38] ‚è∞

4.4. Scenario Analysis & Resilience

We completed organization-wide scenario analysis that covers both our direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[39] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises.[40]

Transition Planning:

We have a climate transition plan which aligns with a 1.5¬∞C world, demonstrating our commitment to strategic alignment with climate goals.[41] üåç

Ongoing Refinement:

We're continuing to refine our understanding of each scenario and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[42] We're currently undertaking a refresh of our scenario models and double materiality assessment, which may further impact our processes and priorities going forward.[43]

We're also engaging biodiversity specialists to help identify additional risks and opportunities, which will enhance our understanding of nature-related dependencies and impacts.[44] üå±

Direct emissions from our operations including combustion of fuel in our ground support equipment and vehicles, as well as gas and other fuel consumption for operating facilities. We use a 2022 baseline year for measuring progress.[61] üöó

Scope 2 Emissions:

Indirect emissions from purchased electricity for our operations and facilities. ‚ö°

Scope 3 Emissions:

We report against 7 categories of Scope 3 greenhouse gas emissions:[62]

  • Category 1 ‚Äì Purchased goods and services
  • Category 2 ‚Äì Capital goods
  • Category 3 ‚Äì Fuel- and energy-related activities (not included in Scope 1 or 2)
  • Category 5 ‚Äì Waste generated in operations
  • Category 6 ‚Äì Business travel
  • Category 7 ‚Äì Employee commuting
  • Category 11 ‚Äì Use of sold products

Verification & Methodology:

Our 2023 GHG emissions have been externally verified to a moderate level of assurance by ESG360, with verification of data obtained from invoices undertaken by Hilltop Sustainability.[63] We use a system called ESG360 to enable more efficient data collection and calculation of our emissions, which follows the global methodology set by the Greenhouse Gas Protocol. ‚úÖ

6.2. Targets

We have established science-based targets to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions in line with a 1.5¬∞C pathway:

2030 Targets:

We have science-based targets to reduce absolute Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions by 50% by 2030 from our 2022 baseline.[64] These targets have been validated by the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi). üéØ

2045 Net-Zero Target:

We're tracking progress toward our net-zero target for 2045, which has also been validated by SBTi.[65] üåç

Management Accountability:

Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions. These targets were refreshed for 2023 and will be further updated in 2024 as we set new targets and update our decision-making processes.[66] We're expanding accountability more widely across the organization, with more employees being responsible for delivery of our sustainability strategy. Management targets will be further refreshed for 2025 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios, risks and opportunities. üí™

Transition Plan:

We have a climate transition plan which aligns with a 1.5¬∞C world.[67] We're planning to develop a standalone transition plan in the next year to further detail our pathway to achieving these targets. üöÄ

7. References / Supporting Reports

This TCFD report has been prepared based on data and analysis from the reporting period January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023. The report draws on information from:

  • Our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system (Corestream)
  • Organization-wide scenario analysis conducted in accordance with TCFD recommendations
  • GHG emissions data verified by ESG360 and Hilltop Sustainability
  • Strategic reviews and risk assessments conducted by our Risk Committee and Risk & Audit Committee
  • Input from senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer

External Standards & Frameworks:

  • Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations
  • Greenhouse Gas Protocol: A Corporate Accounting and Reporting Standard (2004)
  • UK Government's Environmental Reporting Guidelines
  • Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) validation

Next Steps:

We're planning to refresh our scenario modelling and double materiality assessment, and we're engaging biodiversity specialists to help identify additional risks and opportunities. We'll continue to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business. üå±

For more information about our climate strategy and performance, please refer to our annual Sustainability Report and other ESG disclosures. üìã

sourceSlices.answer:

  • Medium-term (6-15 years): Reflects our equipment depreciation cycles and contract lengths
  • Long-term (16-25 years): Supports our net-zero targets validated by SBTi

sourceSlices.question: Does the governance body set, monitor, and incentivise targets clearly aligned to climate related risks and opportunities?
sourceSlices.answer:
Yes, we do set and monitor targets aligned to climate-related risks and opportunities, though our incentive structures are still developing. üéØ

Target Setting & Monitoring:
Our governance body, including the Risk & Audit Committee and Executive Management Board, oversees climate-related targets. Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. These targets were refreshed for 2023 and are being further updated for 2024-2025 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios, risks and opportunities.

The Chief Governance and Sustainability Officer has day-to-day responsibility for sustainability targets and reports directly to the board annually on environmental issues. The Risk & Audit Committee meets quarterly to ensure climate and sustainability-related risks are identified and managed, with oversight of scenario modelling for climate risks.

Incentivisation:
While we have goals assigned to various management teams related to achieving our environmental targets and objectives, these are not yet broad goals at C-suite level. We acknowledge this is a core consideration for the future and plan to introduce monetary incentives for the management of climate change issues within the next two years. üíº

sourceSlices.question: What metrics does the business use to monitor progress towards reaching each climate related targets?
sourceSlices.answer:
Hey! üëã So here's the deal with how we track our climate targets:

Main metrics we're using:

  • Absolute emissions reduction - We're tracking total gross global Scope 1 & 2 emissions in metric tons CO2e to see if we're hitting our reduction targets üìâ
  • Emissions intensity - We monitor combined Scope 1 & 2 emissions per unit currency total revenue (metric tons CO2e per revenue), which gives us an activity-based view that fits our business ops
  • Transport-specific intensity metrics - We use primary intensity (activity-based) metrics for emissions from transport activities across Scope 1, 2, and 3
  • Capital expenditure alignment - We track the % of CAPEX aligned with our climate transition. In 2022 it was 12% (¬£15 million), and we're planning to bump that up to 20% by 2030 üí∞
  • Energy consumption - We monitor total energy consumption in MWh (excluding feedstocks) and track fuel consumption by type
  • Sustainable procurement - We measure progress through our 'electric first' approach to ground support equipment and vehicle investments ‚ö°

Our Board-level governance includes measuring progress towards environmental science-based targets and corporate environmental targets on an annual basis, so there's proper oversight at the top! üéØ

sourceSlices.question: What key assumptions did the business make in the climate related scenario analysis regarding developments in technology?
sourceSlices.answer:
Based on our scenario analysis, we made key assumptions regarding developments in technology, particularly focusing on the transition to lower emissions technology and products. üå±

Our analysis considered:

  • Unsuccessful investment in new technologies as a potential risk factor
  • Data access/availability and monitoring systems as technological considerations
  • The transition to lower emissions technology across our operations

We also assumed a scenario where there could be a social tipping point impacting the aviation sector, with drastic government measures towards the end of the decade. This scenario envisaged growing investor and wider stakeholder focus on the aviation sector, which would drive technological change and innovation in low-carbon solutions. üöÄ

We're planning a detailed reassessment in 2024 to determine the continued validity of these scenarios and assess various indicators, including quantifying the impact of carbon pricing on each scenario to ensure we can include this analysis in our forward planning. üìä

TCFD Report Notes

1. Foreword / Executive Summary

Climate change represents both a critical challenge and an opportunity for our business. We recognize that addressing climate-related risks and capitalizing on emerging opportunities is essential to our long-term success and resilience. üåç

This report outlines our approach to climate governance, strategy, risk management, and performance metrics in alignment with the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations. Throughout 2023, we've strengthened our climate response by:

  • Fully integrating climate risks and opportunities into our Enterprise Risk Management system[1]
  • Developing a climate transition plan aligned with a 1.5¬∞C world[2]
  • Adopting an 'electric first' approach to capital investment decisions[3]
  • Expanding climate-related accountability across senior management[4]

We're committed to transparency and continuous improvement as we navigate the transition to a low-carbon economy. This report demonstrates our progress and outlines our path forward. üéØ

2. Introduction

The Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) provides a framework for organizations to disclose climate-related financial information to stakeholders. Our TCFD reporting covers four core pillars: Governance, Strategy, Risk Management, and Metrics & Targets.

Our TCFD Journey:

We've conducted organization-wide scenario analysis that influences our risk identification, business model resilience, and target setting.[5] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[6]

We're continuing to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[7] We're also planning to refresh our scenario modelling and double materiality assessment, and engaging biodiversity specialists to identify additional risks and opportunities.[8]

Reporting Period: This report covers the period from January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023.

3. Governance

3.1. Board Oversight

Our board-level Risk and Audit Committee provides oversight of climate and sustainability-related risks, ensuring they are properly identified and managed.[9] The Committee has specific oversight of scenario modelling for climate risks, ensuring our approach remains robust and forward-looking.[10]

Our Board of Directors has been engaged throughout the year on our climate strategy. We've used our TCFD framework and scenario analysis to help the Board understand the qualitative impacts of climate change on our business across short, medium, and long-term time horizons.[11]

The Risk Committee reviewed top-down and emerging risks at the end of 2022, with risks quantified using a set methodology. These risks are continuously reviewed by our Risk Committee and board-level Risk and Audit Committee throughout the year.[12] üìä

3.2. Management's Role

Our Executive Management Board has been regularly informed of progress with our Sustainability Strategy throughout the year and has been involved in key initiatives, opportunities and collaborations.[13]

Our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer plays a central role in climate governance, being directly involved in scenario planning exercises and assessment of opportunities and risks.[14]

Climate-Related Targets & Accountability:

Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas emissions.[15] These targets were refreshed for 2023 and will be further updated in 2024 as we set new targets.[16]

We're expanding accountability more widely across the organization, with more employees being held accountable for delivering our sustainability strategy as it relates to climate change.[17] Management targets will be refreshed for 2025 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios, risks and opportunities.[18] üí™

4. Strategy

4.1. Climate-related Risks & Opportunities

We've conducted a comprehensive assessment of climate-related risks and opportunities across our business. Our scenario analysis is organization-wide and covers both our direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[19]

Physical Risks Identified:

We've identified several acute and chronic physical risks that could impact our operations:[20]

  • Acute risks: Floods, wildfires, storms, heat waves, cyclones, heavy precipitation, and drought
  • Chronic risks: Changing precipitation patterns, coastal erosion, heat stress, increased severity of extreme weather events, and sea level rise

These physical risks are assessed as having medium-high magnitude with impacts anticipated over the medium to long-term. üåä

Transition Risks & Opportunities:

We've identified concentration of risks around:[21]

  • Non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation
  • Technology transitions including data access/monitoring systems and transition to lower emissions technology
  • Investment requirements in new technologies

Our 'electric first' approach to investment decisions for ground support equipment and vehicles demonstrates how we're capitalizing on opportunities in the transition to lower-carbon operations.[22] ‚ö°

We've conducted a comprehensive strategic review of our business model and value chain to identify climate-related risks and opportunities.[19] Our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system, Corestream, fully integrates all climate-related risks and opportunities discovered through our TCFD implementation process.[20]

Risk Identification:

We've identified climate risks concentrated in several key areas of our business model and value chain:[21]

  • Regulatory & Liability Exposure: Risks around non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation[22]
  • Technology Risks: Data access/monitoring systems, transition to lower emissions technology, and investment in new technologies[23]
  • Revenue Impact: We've identified that approximately ¬£20M of revenue (1-10% of total) is vulnerable to transition risks, with an additional ¬£5M from physical risks[24]

Opportunities:

We're capitalizing on climate-related opportunities through:

  • Innovation and environmental transformation grants[25]
  • Collaboration with industry partners to drive new technology opportunities and support the aviation services transition[26]
  • Maximizing access to grants and subsidies[27]
  • Collaborating with suppliers on improved leasing terms where sustainability financing provides financial benefits[28]

4.2. Impact on Business, Strategy & Financial Planning

Climate-related risks and opportunities have been integrated into our strategic planning and financial decision-making processes. üíº

Strategic Integration:

We utilize scenario analysis to refine our understanding of climate change impacts on our business, incorporating this analysis into new business opportunity assessments.[29] We've refined our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis outcomes into new business opportunity assessments.[30]

Our scenario analysis directly influences:[31]

  • Risk and opportunities identification, assessment and management
  • Resilience of business model and strategy
  • Target setting and transition planning

Financial Planning Elements Affected:

Climate considerations have impacted several key financial planning elements:

  • Revenues: As noted above, we've identified approximately ¬£20M of revenue vulnerable to transition risks and ¬£5M from physical risks[32]
  • Capital Expenditures (CAPEX): We're taking an 'electric first' approach to all investment decisions for new ground support equipment and vehicles, and we expect increased investment in sustainable solutions to support our net-zero transition[33]
  • Investment Procedures: We've expanded our sustainable procurement approach and capital investment procedures across our business[34]

Decision-Making Updates:

Our decision-making processes are being updated to reflect sustainability and climate change considerations, with plans for further refresh in 2024 following completion of our materiality process and in-depth review of climate scenarios.[35] üìä

4.3. Time Horizons

We've used our TCFD framework and scenario analysis to help our Executive Management Board and Board of Directors understand the qualitative impacts of climate change on our business across short, medium, and long-term time horizons.[36] We're actively working to quantify these impacts to set our strategic direction for mitigating climate risks and maximizing opportunities.[37]

Our strategy considers how our financial performance, cash flow, and financial position will change across all time horizons.[38] ‚è∞

4.4. Scenario Analysis & Resilience

We completed organization-wide scenario analysis that covers both our direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[39] Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer have been directly involved in scenario planning exercises.[40]

Transition Planning:

We have a climate transition plan which aligns with a 1.5¬∞C world, demonstrating our commitment to strategic alignment with climate goals.[41] üåç

Ongoing Refinement:

We're continuing to refine our understanding of each scenario and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[42] We're currently undertaking a refresh of our scenario models and double materiality assessment, which may further impact our processes and priorities going forward.[43]

We're also engaging biodiversity specialists to help identify additional risks and opportunities, which will enhance our understanding of nature-related dependencies and impacts.[44] üå±

5. Risk Management

5.1. Identification & Assessment

We identify and assess climate-related risks and opportunities within our existing Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) system called Corestream.[45] All climate risks and opportunities discovered through our TCFD implementation process are fully integrated within our updated ERM processes and form a core part of our risk assessment procedures.[46]

Risk Categories Assessed:

Transition Risks: üîÑ

  • Policy and legal risks (including non-compliance with regulations and exposure to litigation)
  • Technology risks (data access/monitoring systems, transition to lower emissions technology, investment in new technologies)
  • Market risks (changing customer behavior, uncertainty in market signals, increased cost of raw materials)
  • Reputation risks (shifts in consumer preferences, stigmatization of sector, increased stakeholder concern)

Physical Risks: üåç

  • Acute: Floods, wildfires, storms, heat waves, cyclones, heavy precipitation, drought
  • Chronic: Changing precipitation patterns, coastal erosion, heat stress, increased severity of extreme weather events, sea level rise

Assessment Process:

Senior management and our Chief Governance & Sustainability Officer directly participate in scenario planning exercises to assess opportunities and risks.[47] We conduct awareness sessions on climate change and external factors, and communicate sustainability plans to over 100 senior managers during M100 update sessions.[48]

Our Risk Committee reviewed top-down and emerging risks at the end of 2022, with risks quantified using a set methodology.[49] üìä

5.2. Risk Management Process

Our climate risk management process is embedded within our comprehensive Enterprise Risk Management framework and follows a structured approach:

Regular Review Cycle:

Climate risks are continuously reviewed by our Risk Committee and board-level Risk and Audit Committee throughout the year.[50] Executive and senior management teams assess potential impacts at least twice a year through our ERM system.[51]

Scenario Analysis Integration:

We've refined our risk assessment process to incorporate scenario analysis into new business opportunity assessments.[52] This ensures climate considerations are embedded in strategic decision-making from the outset. Our scenario analysis is organization-wide and covers both direct operations and upstream/downstream value chain.[53]

Cross-Functional Approach:

We have a cross-functional risk group that assesses all enterprise risks and participates in climate risk analysis, ensuring climate considerations are integrated across different internal functions.[54] ü§ù

Ongoing Refinement:

We're continuing to refine our understanding of climate scenarios and develop the strategic and financial implications of climate change on our business.[55] We're also engaging biodiversity specialists to help identify additional risks and opportunities.[56]

5.3. Integration into Overall Risk Management

Climate-related risks and opportunities are fully integrated within our Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) processes and are a core part of our risk assessment procedures.[57] This integration ensures that climate considerations are not treated as separate or siloed issues, but rather as fundamental components of our overall risk landscape. ‚úÖ

Strategic Integration:

Our scenario analysis directly influences:

  • Risk and opportunities identification, assessment and management
  • Resilience of business model and strategy
  • Target setting and transition planning[58]

Governance Linkage:

Our Risk & Audit Committee is responsible for ensuring climate and sustainability-related risks are identified and managed, with oversight of scenario modelling for climate risks.[59] This provides clear accountability and oversight at the board level.

Management Accountability:

Members of senior management have been assigned climate-related targets focused on reducing Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions, ensuring accountability at the management level.[60] We're expanding accountability more widely, with more employees being responsible for delivery of our strategy as it reflects sustainability and climate change.[61] üí™
